title: Procurement & Contracts
description: Select appropriate contract types based on risk tolerance and scope clarity—Fixed Price, Cost Reimbursable, Time & Materials.
objectives: Select appropriate contract type based on risk tolerance and scope clarity
Understand risk allocation between buyer and seller for each contract type
Identify when hybrid contracts (incentive fees, cost ceilings) are appropriate
Apply contract modifications when scope changes

screens.headline: 3 Vendors. 3 Contracts. One Wrong Choice Costs $50K. Which Contract Type for Each?

dialogue.text: Rashid, I've seen companies get burned by bad contracts. Show me you understand risk allocation.

screens.learningHook: Three vendors. Three contracts. Wrong contract type = financial exposure or vendor disputes.

screens.title: Contract Type Selection
screens.instructions: Match each procurement to the appropriate contract type based on scope clarity and risk tolerance.

scenarios.title: Contract Matching Matrix
description: Kitchen Renovation: $150K, well-defined scope, blueprints finalized
Marketing Campaign: $80K, evolving scope, strategy unclear

questions.question: Match each procurement to the appropriate contract type:

feedback.correct: Perfect! Fixed Price for clear scope (buyer low risk). Cost Reimbursable for evolving scope (flexibility). T&M for unpredictable hours (pay for actual work).
feedback.incorrect: Match contract to scope clarity: Fixed Price (clear scope, buyer protected), Cost Reimbursable (evolving scope, flexibility), T&M (unpredictable hours, pay as you go).

questions.question: Why is Fixed Price WRONG for Marketing Campaign?

options.text: Marketing is too expensive for Fixed Price
Unclear scope makes Fixed Price risky—vendor can't estimate, buyer risks change orders
Fixed Price contracts require government approval

feedback.correct: Unclear scope makes Fixed Price risky for BOTH parties. Vendor can't estimate accurately, buyer risks expensive change orders. Cost Reimbursable allows flexibility as scope clarifies.
feedback.incorrect: The issue is scope clarity. Fixed Price works when scope is well-defined. For evolving scope like marketing, Cost Reimbursable provides flexibility without change order disputes.

questions.question: In a Fixed Price contract, who bears the cost overrun risk?

options.text: Buyer (must pay more if costs increase)
Seller (must absorb overruns, still delivers at agreed price)

feedback.correct: Fixed Price = Seller bears cost risk. If costs exceed estimate, seller absorbs overruns. Buyer has cost certainty. That's why Fixed Price requires clear scope—seller needs to estimate accurately.
feedback.incorrect: In Fixed Price contracts, SELLER bears cost risk. If work costs more than estimated, seller absorbs it. Buyer pays agreed price regardless. This is why clear scope is essential.

content.definition: Seller delivers for fixed amount regardless of actual costs
Buyer reimburses actual costs + fee (CPFF, CPIF, CPPC)
Pay for hours at agreed rate + materials

options.benefit: Fixed Price with bonus for under-budget

content.principle: Hybrid contracts balance risk between buyer and seller

correct.text: You understand risk allocation. Fixed Price protects us on clear scope. Cost Reimbursable gives flexibility for creative work. T&M works for unpredictable maintenance. Approved.

partial.text: Close, but reconsider one choice. Review scope clarity vs risk trade-off for each procurement.

incorrect.text: This won't work. You're either exposing us to risk or scaring vendors away. Revisit contract fundamentals.

screens.title: Cost Overrun Crisis
screens.context: Marketing vendor (Cost Reimbursable) submitted $25K invoice in Month 1 (budget $80K for 6 months). Ava is furious: 'This will blow our budget!'

options.text: Switch to Fixed Price contract immediately
Add a cost ceiling (not-to-exceed clause) to the contract
Terminate the contract and find a new vendor
Accept it—Cost Reimbursable means we cover actual costs

questions.question: Why can't you just switch to Fixed Price mid-contract?

options.text: It's illegal to change contract types
Scope is still evolving—Fixed Price requires clear scope, plus vendor must agree
Fixed Price contracts are more expensive

screens.title: Procurement & Contracts Mastery
screens.summary: Contract type selection depends on scope clarity and risk tolerance. Match the contract to the work, not the other way around.
takeaways: Fixed Price: Buyer low risk, seller high risk (clear scope required)
Cost Reimbursable: Buyer high risk, seller low risk (evolving scope)
Time & Materials: Buyer medium risk, seller low risk (unpredictable hours)
Hybrid options (incentive fees, cost ceilings) balance risk
Contract type determines WHO bears the risk

artifacts.title: Contract Selection Matrix
artifacts.description: Risk allocation comparison table for contract types

characterClosing.text: Kitchen renovation gets Fixed Price (clear scope, we know the cost). Marketing gets Cost Reimbursable with a ceiling (flexibility + protection). Maintenance gets T&M (pay for actual hours). Right contract for right scope.
